action.action-desc: Mr. Engel (for himself, Ms. Ros-Lehtinen, Mr. Israel, and Mr. Cole) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To amend chapter 329 of title 49, United States Code, to ensure that new vehicles enable fuel competition so as to reduce the strategic importance of oil to the United States.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Open Fuel Act of 2015.

section.header: Open fuel requirement for motor vehicles
section.text: Chapter 329 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by inserting after section 32905 the following new section:

section.header: Open fuel requirement for motor vehicles.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c), each manufacturer’s fleet of covered vehicles for a particular model year shall be comprised of—

paragraph.text: not less than 30 percent qualified vehicles beginning in model year 2018; and
not less than 50 percent qualified vehicles beginning in model year 2019 and each subsequent year.
the term covered vehicle means a passenger automobile, and includes a light-duty motor vehicle;
the term qualified vehicle means covered vehicle that—

subparagraph.text: has been warranted by its manufacturer to operate on natural gas, hydrogen, or biodiesel;
is a plug-in electric drive vehicle;
is propelled solely by a fuel cell that produces power without the use of petroleum or a petroleum-based fuel; or
is propelled solely by something other than an internal combustion engine, and produces power without the use of petroleum or a petroleum-based fuel;

paragraph.text: the term flexible fuel vehicle means a vehicle that has been warranted by its manufacturer to operate on gasoline, E85, and M85;
the term E85 means a fuel mixture containing up to 85 percent ethanol and meets the standards of ASTM D5798;
the term M85 means a fuel mixture containing up to 85 percent methanol and meets the standards of ASTM D5797;
the term biodiesel means diesel fuel which has been produced from a non-petroleum feedstock and which meets the standards of ASTM D6751–03;
the term plug-in electric drive vehicle has the meaning given such term in section 508(a)(5) of the Energy Policy Act of 1992 (42 U.S.C. 13258(a)(5)); and

the term light-duty motor vehicle means a light-duty truck or light-duty vehicle as such terms are defined in section 216(7) of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7550(7)) of less than or equal to 8,500 pounds gross vehicle weight rating.

A manufacturer may request an exemption from the requirement described in subsection (a) by submitting an application to the Secretary, at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Secretary may require by regulation. Each such application shall specify the models, lines, and types of automobiles affected.

After evaluating an application received from a manufacturer, the Secretary may at any time, under such terms and conditions, and to such extent as the Secretary considers appropriate, temporarily exempt, or renew the exemption of, a light-duty motor vehicle from the requirement described in subsection (a) if the Secretary determines that unavoidable events not under the control of the manufacturer prevent the manufacturer of such automobile from meeting its required production volume of qualified automobiles, including—

subparagraph.text: a disruption in the supply of any component required for compliance with the regulations; or
a disruption in the use and installation by the manufacturer of such component.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may consolidate applications received from multiple manufacturers under subparagraph (A) if they are of a similar nature.

Any exemption granted under paragraph (2) shall be conditioned upon the manufacturer’s commitment to recall the exempted automobiles for installation of the omitted components within a reasonable time proposed by the manufacturer and approved by the Secretary after such components become available in sufficient quantities to satisfy both anticipated production and recall volume requirements.
The Secretary shall publish in the Federal Register—

subparagraph.text: notice of each application received from a manufacturer;
notice of each decision to grant or deny a temporary exemption; and
the reasons for granting or denying such exemptions.

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall promulgate regulations as necessary to carry out this section.
